item.description: As you add more panels to your dashboard, more requests are being made, potentially leading to your dashboard taking longer to load. item.title: Learn Grafana: How to automatically repeat rows and panels in dynamic dashboards
item.description: Running your software on dynamic infrastructure means that your monitoring platform needs to change dynamically. Variables let you reuse a single dashboard for all your services. In this blog post, we‚Äôll look at how you can dynamically add and remove entire panels through a feature called repeated panels.

item.description: I‚Äôm writing this on the way home from GolangUK where I did a talk on Building an Enterprise Service in Go, based on the DDD Sample App. I was really overwhelmed with the positive feedback I got, some of which came from developers who never heard of DDD prior to my talk. item.title: Domain Driven Design in Go: Part 3
item.description: Up until now, we have only looked at one service in isolation, but this is seldom the case in a service-oriented architecture. For the last post in this blog series on Domain Driven Design in Go we will have a look at how we interact with other services. In particular, we will have a look at two concepts that help us reason about these interactions: application services and bounded contexts.

item.title: Writing a Go client for your RESTful API
item.description: By providing your users with a client SDK in their favorite language you are making it even easier to integrate their services with yours. In this blog post I will show you how to write your own client package in Go!

item.title: Domain Driven Design in Go: Part 2
item.description: In my previous post I announced a project I have been tinkering with lately; porting an existing DDD sample application to Go. item.title: Domain Driven Design in Go: Part 1
item.description: In 2008, Citerus developed a Java sample application in close collaboration with Eric Evans, based on the examples in his book.
